body: @michaelschiff so where the aggregation is happening ?

@b-slim in the StatsD server. This can be run on the same machine or remotely. If on the same machine, you just size appropriately for the multiple processes, but a crash in the StatsD process should not impact the druid process

There is an interesting mix of standardized and non standardized auth methods here. On one hand the authorization tries to provide a standard resource related framework, but on the other hand it completely relies on the endpoint to do all the auth requesting and logic.

I suspect this is because the resource of interest is contained within the body rather than as part of the http request metadata.

IMHO a "cleaner" solution would be to architect the requests such that any endpoint that touches a sensitive resource must have the appropriate annotations on what resources it touches. Then the auth layer transparently handles the auth based on request metadata, and the duty within the endpoint itself is simply to wire up the authorized resource to the resource actually being used.

Another way to say it is that it would be awesome if by the time the method is called, the auth system has already performed its function, and it is simply the job of the endpoint method to ensure compliance with the auth system's expectations on resource usage.

Yes the auth checks are performed inside endpoints as many of the Druid endpoints does not follow REST conventions and resource information is inside the body.
So the cleaner approach that you are suggesting is to change the endpoints to follow REST conventions ? Is that what you meant when you said the requests must have appropriate annotations ?
@drcrallen your suggestion is valid, however something that can be done independently of this PR and would probably require druid client API changes.
@navis any chance of finishing this up?

This looks like it is implementing what Xavier spec'd out, but Xavier spec'd it out for 0.9.0 as a backwards incompatible change.  Now that this is set for 0.9.1, should we 
1. Wait for 0.10.0 to actually release
2. Do it in 0.9.1 anyway
3. Do it in a backwards compatible manner for now

If #3, I think we can do that by keeping "error" as the same value that it is today and maybe add "errorType" as what Xavier spec'd out as "error"?
I believe, if its ready, we should just put it in 0.9.0 .

@b-slim I have a high degree of confidence this will fix locking issues, but almost zero information on if this offers better latency than the guava cache. Luckily it is in an extension so it is completely optional.

Does caffeine have any way to use a global retention rule, but divide the keys up into namespaces?

@himanshug / @pjain1 would you guys feel comfortable calling auth an experimental feature that may change significantly in the near-ish future?

If that's the case then a stop-gap that solves your main pain points should be ok as long as its not intrusive in other scenarios (which I don't think this PR is)

General PR comments:
- Headers missing  on some of the files
- Why are enums needed instead of just strings?
@pjain1 please comment in the code where you're adding the auth checks that auth is experimental and reference this PR. ((so future developers know why it is there))

No, but it might be possible to build something like that on top. It is a little vague of what that means and how generally useful it is. I've seen it discussed in contexts of other caches, but it was never requested for Guava's.

Namespaces used to be asked for a lot back in memcached's heyday. Most of the time it was to invalidate a bunch of keys together which were inter-related. The solution was to use [generational caching](http://www.regexprn.com/2011/06/web-application-caching-strategies_05.html) (a version number as part of the key) and increment the generation when the data store was updated. That relied on the cache to lazily evict the old keys which wouldn't be used anymore.

Alternatively you could build indexes and rely on locking since this is part of the same process. A `CacheWriter` could be useful to make insertion / eviction atomic with a separate multimap (namespace to keys).

If namespaces are to make regions to have sub and global thresholds, this is even messier. That's usually to share a cluster of memcached and perform resource accounting (e.g. Google's internal rewrite did this) or have an automatic cache sizing. The former makes no sense here, the latter is very messy in Java where GC masks sizes. Attempts to do it automatically (soft references, heap monitoring, etc) don't work well. Its better to be explicit and move large scale caching outside of the JVM (off-heap, memcached, etc).

So messy and confusing from my side of the fence. I think the useful hooks are exposed for a custom job, though.

@ben-manes the big thing for use in druid is that the data queries have the underlying data segment as part of the cache key. As such, if the segment is no longer present on a node (in the case of using local cache) then that node will no longer receive queries for that segment, so any sort of LRU-like eviction policy should favor destroying those no-longer-used keys.

The current methodology in this PR is similar to the generational approach you described, but the existing cache keys are scanned and invalidated in a best-effort manner. It could just fall back to lazy eviction if performance is a concern for actively scanning the keys.
Thanks for the insight.

If you know when a segment is no longer present then you could maintain an index as described above. Then when the segment is dropped you invalidate all of the associated keys. This could be done racy (depending on eviction to cleanup) or atomically (a bit of locking) depending on your preference. The atomic approach might use a [CacheWriter](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Writer) (synchronous) or [RemovalListener](https://github.com/ben-manes/caffeine/wiki/Removal#removal-listeners) (asynchronous). The complexity to do it "correctly" and discard data proactively may not turn into a performance win, though.

@drcrallen sure I will put the necessary comments. I will put the headers. 
About Enum vs String - I chose enums as it gives more control on what values can be passed in and all the options available to the developer but I also see the point that anyways `AuthorizationInfo` will be implemented by extensions they can pass in whatever they want. Personally I would prefer enum but I am OK in changing it to String if you have a strong opinion against using enum. BTW what is your reason of not having enums ?

@pjain1 good points. My reasons for not favoring enums are:
- Enums are not very extensible, and IMHO make more sense when either A) there is an explicit requirement for ordering or B) There is an explicit need to limit the options available
- I'm not sure how well enums play with classloaders. I'm guessing they don't any more so than other classes. Getting an error message like "`DATASOURCE` cannot be assigned to type `ResourceType`" (or similar) is pretty irritating. This can occur if the two enum classes were loaded through different classLoaders.

So basically, if you're trying to force any extensions to ONLY use the values presented, and not intending the security set to be extendable, then there can be a good argument for enums.

@nishantmonu51 

RE: null handling, the nulls are being converted to 0.  It's not in this PR, but a follow on PR that I am finishing up:

https://github.com/jon-wei/druid/blob/5bffacec5772718bcb948b81e6ace4192d940396/processing/src/main/java/io/druid/segment/IndexMerger.java#L1432

That PR reuses the existing single-value long/float column formats for the numeric dims, representing null without changes to the storage format (need some mechanism to distinguish null from normal values) or using dictionary encoding (have a dictionary entry for null) seems problematic. Throwing an exception sounds okay to me too (maybe let user configure? choice of "throw exception" or "convert null to 0")

RE: docs and tests, this open PR doesn't actually enable the use of long/float dimensions, it's just preparing IncrementalIndex for later changes:
- It doesn't provide a way to specify dimension typing in the schema
- No query/filter/extraction fn, etc. support for long/floats yet

I address those points and have tests in the follow-on patch (not ready yet), I think it would make more sense to include docs in the later PR when the numeric dims are actually usable

@gianm @fjy yes that is correct, they are not memory bound but growth with n is not linear.
i spoke to the local experts about this and the reason to make this choice is to be able to provide predictable errors independent of input distribution and still be able to be fast enough.
@drcrallen the part that fixes #2428 by including extensionUrls in the classloader looks ok.

@gianm I added a new coordinator endpoint to get list of used segments given a dataSource and list of intervals which looks like..

```
POST /druid/coordinator/v1/metadata/datasources/{dataSourceName}/segments

body - [interval1, interval2,...]
```

I don't like it being a POST api but can't think of a cleaner way of getting list of intervals in a GET based api. thoughts?
@himanshug I think POST is ok, it makes it a lot easier to deal with potentially large intervals lists that are too big for the url.

@himanshug this looks good to me, one issue remaining is that users could accidentally lose ingested data if the following happens,

1) process A starts a delta ingestion using this method, it fails
2) process B updates that interval with some new data
3) process A starts a delta ingestion using this method, it succeeds, wiping away data from (2)

or even,

1) process A reads list of segments
2) process B updates data for that interval
3) process A submits delta ingest job, wiping away data from (2)

This could be addressed using overlord locking, by having the hadoop task check on start that the segments in the ingestion spec actually correspond to the currently-used segments. Then the retry would be both idempotent and safe (it would protect against the race above).

if you prefer not to do this now, then I think this PR could go through as-is (since the method in this PR works OK if there is some external locking on the user's side) but we should file an issue to fix this for the case where the is no external locking.
@gianm added the check to be safe as well as idempotent.
@drcrallen please check the new changes !

@fjy we will start using segmentMetadata query, but note that we have many druid clusters with different teams managing those. I am notifying the users internally for this deprecation and asking to use segmentMetadata query but we should not remove these endpoints for at least a quarter more and it is proven that segmentMetadata query is truly efficient enough to replace those.
@liqweed Thanks for the info! I will check it out.

I'm working on a pr to fix this and so far it seems that it will be a bit of a challenge to get those benchmarks going again. Bumping caliper to 1.0-beta-2 requires bumping Guava to 18.0. This in turn breaks quite a bit of Druid code, which uses deprecated features that have been removed since 16.0.1.

@himanshug segmentMetadata will not be as efficient as these endpoints, but with caching enabled and restriction of analysisTypes, it should be able to get pretty close and should be 'efficient enough'.

FYI the query that we use for metadata is:

``` json
{
  "queryType": "segmentMetadata",
  "dataSource": "datasource",
  "merge": true,
  "analysisTypes": []
}
```

and in 0.9.0 will change to:

``` json
{
  "queryType": "segmentMetadata",
  "dataSource": "datasource",
  "merge": true,
  "analysisTypes": [
    "aggregators"
  ],
  "lenientAggregatorMerge": true
}
```

I also think there is no need to remove the broker endpoints any time soon, but would like to encourage people to use segmentMetadata anyway as it is generally "better" (it shows dimensions on realtime, it gives more info about column types and capabilities, in 0.9.0, aggregations)

@guobingkun  @liqweed Copycat did come up in a survey we did last year and we did not use it at the time for a few reasons,
- it requires java 8 and we were not ready to require java 8 for Druid users.
- it was labeled "not production ready" on the github site (https://github.com/atomix/copycat).
- we did not find any other projects using it in production.

It seems to have matured a lot since then (I don't recall the jepsen tests existing back then) and we are probably somewhat closer to being ready to require java 8. Although, the github site still says "beta - not production ready". @liqweed are you involved with the project? Do you have any insight into what exactly that means?

We cannot bump druid guava above 16.0.1 due to hadoop incompatibilities.

The stuff under the `benchmark` directory worked last time I checked (and we were using guava 16.0.1)

Can you elaborate more on the error you are seeing?
@fjy I've removed commented code and added Deprecated tag.

The benchmarks I'm talking about are not inside `benchmark` directory.

The one I'm specifically interested in is `io.druid.query.aggregation.hyperloglog.HyperLogLogCollectorBenchmark` from `processing` module. All the other failing benchmarks are located in `processing` and `server` (the last one) modules. 

The error is as described above. The `com.google.caliper.Runner` attempts to call the `com.google.common.io.Closeables.closeQuietly` method which is always going fail under Guava 16.0.1, since this method has been removed from Guava API between versions 15.0 and 16.0 (see: http://docs.guava-libraries.googlecode.com/git-history/v16.0/jdiff/changes.html).

Benchmarks I'm talking about are probably broken since Guava was bumped to 16.0.1, over a year and a half ago.
If Guava can't be bumped above 16.0.1, then the only way to fix those benchmarks is to go back to `15.0`, or rewrite them completely from scratch, without Caliper.
awesome @himanshug, will take a look.

Thank you @turu for offering to fix the benchmarks. I don't think we want or even can downgrade Guava. I faced this problem a while back. Caliper completely changed their Api and didn't seem to provide a way to dump results on the console last time I looked at upgrading to 1.0. I basically gave up on caliper at that point and decided it wasn't worth my time. 

I looked a little bit at using junit-benchmark but it appears that has also been deprecated in favor of JMH since I last looked. 

Going forward I believe we should be using JMH for any serious microbenchmark. We already have a couple on JMH, and if you'd like to help porting the remaining ones that would be awesome!

Let us know if you need help

This issue is related to: #2434
if the JS postagg could accept `"fields"` and #2433 was done then this problem would be totally solved.
@vogievetsky I think the JS postagg can already take other postaggs as fieldNames so would it be ok to close this and just do #2433?

Tough call between bug vs improvement, will call it a bug since the old behavior could mask errors on createPathIfNeeded during the worker's "start", leading to MMs that are up but actually failed to create their task and announcement paths.

Potential solution is to set OutOfMemoryException in `_JAVA_OPTIONS` environment variable.

`_JAVA_OPTIONS=-XX:OnOutOfMemoryError="kill -9 %p"`

should work

Minor request for debug logging instead of complete suppression, otherwise :+1:  at author's discretion.
